head.title: Branched Copper Oxide Nanoparticles Induce Highly Selective Ethylene Production by Electrochemical Carbon Dioxide Reduction | Journal of the American Chemical Society

meta.content: Branched Copper Oxide Nanoparticles Induce Highly Selective Ethylene Production by Electrochemical Carbon Dioxide Reduction

For long-term storage of renewable energy, the electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) offers a promising option for converting electricity to permanent forms of chemical energy. In this work, we present highly selective ethylene production dependent upon the catalyst morphology using copper oxide nanoparticles. The branched CuO nanoparticles were synthesized and then deposited on conductive carbon materials. After activation, the major copper species changed to Cu+, and the resulting electrocatalyst exhibited a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) of ethylene reaching over 70% and a hydrogen FE of 30% without any byproducts in a neutral aqueous solution. The catalyst also showed high durability (up to 12 h) with the ethylene FE over 65%. Compared to cubic morphology, the initial branched copper oxide structure formed highly active domains with interfaces and junctions in-between during activation, which caused large surface area with high local pH leading to high selectivity and activity for ethylene production.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to Journal of the American Chemical Society

img.alt: Go to Journal of the American Chemical Society

div.p:
For long-term storage of renewable energy, the electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO
2
RR) offers a promising option for converting electricity to permanent forms of chemical energy. In this work, we present highly selective ethylene production dependent upon the catalyst morphology using copper oxide nanoparticles. The branched CuO nanoparticles were synthesized and then deposited on conductive carbon materials. After activation, the major copper species changed to Cu
+
, and the resulting electrocatalyst exhibited a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) of ethylene reaching over 70% and a hydrogen FE of 30% without any byproducts in a neutral aqueous solution. The catalyst also showed high durability (up to 12 h) with the ethylene FE over 65%. Compared to cubic morphology, the initial branched copper oxide structure formed highly active domains with interfaces and junctions in-between during activation, which caused large surface area with high local pH leading to high selectivity and activity for ethylene production.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Owing to increasing concerns about global warming issues, carbon dioxide is a target molecule that must be managed to limit harmful changes in the planetary ecosystem. Among numerous ways to manage the carbon dioxide level in air, reductive conversion of this gas into value-added compounds is regarded as an eventual goal to resolve the problem permanently. In particular, the electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO
2
RR) has recently attracted much attention because the cost of electricity generated from solar and wind energy sources is rapidly becoming comparable to petroleum-based processes.

To approach highly efficient electrochemical CO
2
RR, group 11 metals have generally been investigated as electrocatalysts due to their low binding affinity to carbon monoxide,
(1−4)
which is known as a major intermediate during the reaction. Copper, in particular, has a moderate binding energy with carbon monoxide, which allows it to generate a variety of hydrocarbons, such as methane, formate, methanol, ethylene, ethanol, and longer-chain hydrocarbon products.
(5−13)
However, its low selectivity toward the desired products, and its vulnerability to the reaction environment, hardly enable copper from being an efficient electrocatalyst.

Many researchers have tried to overcome these hurdles by controlling the catalyst morphology,
(7,9,10,12,14)
support materials,
(8)
and electrolyte conditions.
(15,16)
Oxide-derived copper from copper films is the most famous catalyst structure thus far, due to its highly selective production of formate or ethylene as well as its simple preparation. Copper nanodendrites deposited on the electrode in the presence of halides reached the selective formation of ethylene up to a Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 57%, although the efficiency suddenly decreased.
(9)
Electrodeposition using a sol–gel copper precursor formed copper dendrites, which gave a peak FE of 52% for C
2+
products.
(17)
Oxygen plasma roughened the copper surface and recorded the ethylene FE of 60% with the observation of Cu
+
as major species.
(6)
Importantly, the distinct synthetic process of copper catalyst on the electrode induced a large difference of reduced products including carbon monoxide, methane, formic acid, acetate, ethylene, and ethanol. The product selectivity may be directly correlated with the active copper species and morphology during the reaction, but the catalyst composition had a nearly random distribution of Cu, Cu
2
O, and CuO, and the surface structure generally contained as an irregular mixture of wires, particles, and their aggregates. Due to this severe heterogeneity, there were still multiple factors suggested to be deterministic for high FEs, including high electric fields arising from sharp edges, local pH, Cu species on the catalyst surface, and oxygen contents beneath the surface.
(2,5,6,8,14−23)

On the other hand, although rarely reported, the catalyst using copper nanoparticles provided significant information on the dependency of catalyst morphology. Copper nanoparticles densely packed on the surface led to the generation of C
2
–C
3
hydrocarbons, with the FE reaching 50% at lowered overpotentials.
(5)
Cu nanocubes with different edge lengths exhibited high ethylene FE of 41%, revealing the importance of balancing plane and edge sites.
(14)
In the latter case, however, serious nanoclustering occurred during the reaction, which largely altered the reaction activity and selectivity.
(24)

In the present work, we employed two different morphologies of copper oxide nanoparticles, branched CuO and cubic Cu
2
O, to explore the surface morphology effect influencing product selectivity more directly. The particles were employed as electrocatalysts for CO
2
RR in aqueous solution at pH 7.3. After the catalyst activation, Cu
+
was the major species in both nanoparticles, indicating that either initial composition or oxidation state did not directly influence reaction properties. The branched particles showed a remarkable FE of more than 70% for ethylene alone without any byproducts except hydrogen, while the cubic particles exhibited an FE of only half as much under identical conditions. Although the initial morphology was disintegrated during activation, the branched structure effectively generated highly active small domains in a few nm diameter bearing a number of interfaces and junctions in-between. The high surface area of these small domains provided a high local pH during the reaction, which suppressed hydrogen evolution and substantially increased ethylene selectivity. Despite the formation of active surfaces, the catalyst sustained the ethylene FE more than 65% for 10 h, indicative of the stabilization by conductive carbon materials. In comparison with the cubic structure, the catalyst morphology is one of the detrimental factors for selectivity and activity of electrochemical CO
2
RR, as well as the presence of Cu
+
as major species.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: Synthesis of Copper Oxide Nanoparticles and Fabrication of Catalyst Electrodes
div.div:
We synthesized cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles through a polyol process in the presence of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) in 1,5-pentanediol (
Figure
1
).
(25)
The transmission electron microscope (TEM) image shows that a regular cubic morphology with sharp edges was formed with an average edge size of 60 ± 8 nm (
Figure
1
b inset). Slow oxidation of the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles by an aqueous ammonia solution at room temperature yielded branched CuO nanoparticles via the dissolution and reprecipitation mechanism (
Figure
1
a).
(25)
The TEM images show sharp branches covering the surface with average diameter of 130 ± 30 nm (
Figure
1
c inset).

div.p:
Figure 1. Characterization of copper oxide nanoparticles and their hybrids. (a) Synthetic scheme of branched CuO nanoparticles from the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles. TEM images of (insets) nanoparticles and their hybrids with Ketjen black using (b) cubic Cu
2
O and (c) branched CuO. XRD spectra of the hybrids using (d) cubic Cu
2
O and (e) branched CuO nanoparticles. The bars represent 100 nm.

div.div:
The particles were deposited on Ketjen black carbon to fabricate conductive electrode materials. The particle dispersion was mixed with Ketjen black carbon in ethylene glycol, and the resulting mixture was completely dried under vacuum. The TEM images show that the particles made good contact with the carbon materials (
Figures
1
b and
1
c). The weight percent of the copper was found to be 40% and 37% for the cubic Cu
2
O and branched CuO nanoparticles, respectively, using inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data show three strong peaks at 25, 44, and 79° originating from Ketjen black carbon (
Figure S1
, Supporting Information) and weak but distinct peaks at 35.5 and 39° (
Figure
1
d), and 36.5° (
Figure
1
e) from copper oxide nanoparticles. These peaks indicate that there was no change of copper oxidation state before or after the hybrid formation (
Figures
1
d and
1
e).

div.h3:
Potential Dependence of Electrochemical CO
2
RR Using Copper Oxide Nanoparticles
div.div:
The as-prepared copper oxide-carbon hybrid dispersion was drop-casted on glassy carbon electrodes with an area of 0.50 cm
2
. Electrochemical CO
2
RR was conducted using a handmade three-electrode H-cell with the former electrode as working, Pt as counter, and Ag/AgCl as reference electrode in a CO
2
saturated 0.1 M KHCO
3
buffer solution (pH 7.3) with continuous CO
2
bubbling. The electrochemical cell was connected directly to a gas chromatograph equipped with a pulse discharge detector (PDD) and flame ionization detector (FID) for the quantification of gas products. Prior to the electrochemical CO
2
RR, the catalysts were electrochemically activated at −3.0 V vs Ag/AgCl for 10 min.

The applied potential was varied during the CO
2
RR using the catalyst electrode. At low potentials, CO and H
2
were the major products, and the maximum Faradaic efficiency (FE) for CO was nearly 50% at −0.7 V vs reference hydrogen electrode (RHE), using the branched CuO as an electrocatalyst (
Figure
2
a). However, at high potentials, the CO production suddenly dropped, and the formation of ethylene increased. At −1.0 V vs RHE, the ethylene FE approached the maximum of 53%, whereas the FE of CO was only 5%. Under this condition, the FE of H
2
was 24%, and methane production was negligible. On the other hand, when using the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles, similar trends of CO and ethylene production were observed, but with much lower FEs (
Figure
2
b). At all potentials, H
2
was the major product with FE higher than 42% at least. CO was generated with the maximum FE of 31% at −0.55 V vs RHE, and ethylene reached 32% at −1.0 V vs RHE. A small, but significant amount of methane was generated at potentials higher than −1.0 V.

div.p:
Figure 2. Electrocatalytic profiles of copper oxide nanoparticles. (a, b) FEs and (c, d) current densities at various applied potentials of H
2
(red), ethylene (blue), CO (orange), and methane (green) using (a, c) branched CuO and (b, d) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles as electrocatalysts.

div.div:
The total current density increased as the negative potential increased. At −1.0 V vs RHE, the total current density was −22.0 mA/cm
2
, in which the partial current density of ethylene was −13.5 mA/cm
2
for the branched CuO nanoparticles (
Figure
2
c). In high ranges of potential, the partial current density of H
2
was the only measure comparable to that of ethylene, and the current densities of other products were less than −1 mA/cm
2
. Under the identical conditions used for the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles, the maximum partial current density of ethylene was −5.3 mA/cm
2
, nearly one-third of the value for the branched CuO, and the total current density (−17.7 mA/cm
2
) was a little lower (
Figure
2
d).

The electrochemical activity was highly dependent on the electrolyte concentration. When 0.5 M KHCO
3
was used in the presence of the branched CuO nanoparticles, the FE of ethylene decreased to 36%, whereas the FEs of H
2
and methane increased to 53% and 5%, respectively (
Figure S2a
, Supporting Information). Due to the high electrolyte concentration, the total current density increased to −46.3 mA/cm
2
, and the partial current densities of H
2
and ethylene were −25.3 and −17.2 mA/cm
2
, respectively (
Figure S2c
, Supporting Information). However, we also observed that the effect of the catalyst morphology was still significant. When the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles were used, the FE of ethylene was 24% and that of H
2
more than 75% (
Figure S2b
, Supporting Information). The partial current density of ethylene was only −2.3 mA/cm
2
, due to the bad selectivity for ethylene production (
Figure S2d
, Supporting Information).

div.h3:
Temporal Behavior of Electrochemical CO
2
RR Using Copper Oxide Nanoparticles
div.div:
Catalyst stability is a critical factor for practical applications requiring long-term electrochemical reaction. The copper oxide catalysts were tested at fixed potential of −1.05 V vs RHE, where both branched CuO and cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles exhibited maximum ethylene FEs. After the activation, the FE and current density of CO
2
RR was measured for 12 h (
Figure
3
). Early in the reaction, the FE of ethylene began at 52%, but suddenly increased to 70% within 100 min, when using the branched CuO nanoparticles (
Figure
3
a). Then, the FE was invariable at the level of 70% for up to 550 min. At 330 min, a small peak appeared with the maximum FE of 76%. In the late periods, the FE of ethylene slowly decreased, but still maintained a level greater than 65% for 720 min. We repeated the experiments under the identical reaction conditions twice more, and the maximum of the average FE was estimated to be 68 ± 5% (
Figure S3 and S4
, Supporting Information). More surprisingly, other products such as CO, methane, and ethane showed negligible FEs during all periods. Only H
2
was generated with an FE of ∼30%. The total FE reached 100%, meaning that liquid products rarely formed during the reaction. Actually, liquid products such as formate and ethanol, although detected in the NMR spectrum, totaled less than 0.5% in each CO
2
RR cycle (
Figure S5a
, Supporting Information). This means that the generation of only two products, ethylene and hydrogen, is a notable characteristic of our branched CuO catalyst, making it superior to the other catalysts reported thus far.
(5−10,12,14−17,26−29)
The total negative current and current density increased with time (
Figures
3
c and
S6
, Supporting Information). The partial current density of ethylene suddenly increased within 100 min, and when the value reached −17 mA/cm
2
, the increment slowed down. The current density of ethylene at the maximum FE at 330 min was −19.2 mA/cm
2
, comparable to those of the other catalysts.
(7,26−29)
The FE of H
2
increased linearly from the beginning to 720 min. The continuous increase of the total and H
2
current densities during the reaction was mainly due to the background activity of Ketjen black carbon and nafion (
Figure S7
, Supporting Information).

div.p:
Figure 3. Temporal change of electrochemical CO
2
RR. (a, b) Faradaic efficiency and (c, d) current density changes with the time progress using (a, c) branched CuO and (b, d) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles as electrocatalysts for 12 h. The lines represent H
2
(red), ethylene (blue), CO (orange), methane (green), ethane (pink), and total (black), respectively.

div.div:
In contrast, when using the cubic Cu
2
O particles, the ethylene FE started at the maximum value of 36%, but rapidly decreased to a negligible value at 10 h (
Figure
3
b). The current density also decreased from −5.8 mA/cm
2
to zero within 10 h (
Figure
3
d). Instead, the FE and partial current density of H
2
suddenly increased, reaching more than 90% and −24 mA/cm
2
at 12 h, respectively. The liquid products were less than 0.3% of the total FE including various products detected in the NMR spectrum (
Figure S5b
, Supporting Information). Consistently in these experiments, the branched CuO nanoparticles showed superior reaction performances to that of the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles for ethylene production.

div.h3:
Active Species and Morphology of Copper Oxide Catalysts before and after Electrochemical CO
2
RR
div.div:
To understand the difference between the branched CuO and cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles for CO
2
RR, various methods for surface characterization were attempted. It is known that surface morphology and surface copper species present are two of the most critical factors determining electrochemical activity.
(17)
After the activation of copper oxide nanoparticles, the distinctive peaks corresponding to copper oxides disappeared in the XRD spectra, indicating that the crystallinity of each catalyst changed to a polycrystalline state with very small domain sizes (
Figure S1b
and
S1c
, Supporting Information). The oxidation state of copper was estimated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (
Figure
4
).
(30,31)
Before the activation, the branched CuO nanoparticles showed a pure Cu
2+
peak at 933.5 eV in the Cu 2p
3/2
region, and a peak at 569 eV in the Auger Cu LMM region. The cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles had a sharp Cu
+
(or Cu(0)) peak at 932.5 eV with a small Cu
2+
shoulder at 933.5 eV in the Cu 2p
3/2
region due to native surface oxides. In the Auger Cu LMM region, a peak appeared at 570 eV, corresponding to the Cu
+
species. After activation, the peaks were nearly identical for both nanoparticles. Sharp Cu
+
(or Cu(0)) peaks at 932.5 eV and broad Cu
2+
peaks at 933.5 eV appeared in the Cu 2p region. In the Auger Cu LMM region, both nanoparticles showed an identical peak maximum at 570 eV, the same as the peak of Cu
+
species for the pristine Cu
2
O nanoparticles. The small shoulders at 567 eV were assignable to the Cu(0) species. It should be noted that the original compositions of branched and cubic copper oxide nanoparticles were definitely different as Cu
2+
and Cu
+
, but the major copper species changed to be Cu
+
in both cases after the activation at the high reduction potential. This matches with the in situ observations in copper thin-films, where Cu
+
was reported to be very stable even at highly negative potentials, which could provide a significant amount of leftover Cu
+
or Cu
2
O as active species during the CO
2
RR.
(6,17,28)
Although surface oxidation could lightly occur during the ex situ measurement, Cu
+
was detected as a dominant species.
(6,24)
The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) measurement also supported that both branched CuO and cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles have nearly identical species of Cu
+
and Cu(0) after the activation. The activated catalysts have three distinctive absorption peaks at ∼8982, 8995, and 9003 eV, which were identified by the peaks of Cu
2
O (purple) and Cu foils (black) as in
Figure
5
. Although the limit of these ex situ experiments, reduced Cu(0) and Cu
+
species were clearly distinguished after the reaction for 12 h, also indicating high stability of Cu
+
under the reductive conditions (
Figure
4
b).

div.p:
Figure 4. Characterization of surface copper species. X-ray photoelectron spectra of branched CuO and cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles in the catalyst electrodes before and after the activation in the regions of (a) Cu 2p and (b) Auger Cu LMM. The dotted lines represent the binding energies of Cu(0), Cu
+
, and Cu
2+
species according to the literature.
(30,31)

Figure 5. XANES spectra of (a) branched CuO and (b) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles in the catalyst electrodes ex situ before and after the activation.

div.div:
However, the catalyst morphology was definitely distinct between branched and cubic nanoparticles even after the activation. The original branched morphology was disintegrated into small domains after the activation (
Figure
6
a), which were stabilized on the conductive carbon materials without any dissolution of copper species in solution (
Figure S8
, Supporting Information). The resulting disintegrated morphology was unchanged after the electrochemical CO
2
RR for 12 h (
Figures
6
b,
6
c, and
S9
, Supporting Information). On the other hand, the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles turned into hollow cubic structure with thick shells, and maintained the external cubic framework after prolonged periods of reaction (
Figures
6
d–f). This hollow formation was attributed to oxygen abstraction from the Cu
2
O lattice, as was observed in the reduction of metal oxide nanoparticles.
(32,33)

div.p:
Figure 6. Temporal morphology change during electrochemical CO
2
RR. TEM images of (a–c) branched CuO and (d–f) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles (a, d) after the activation, (b, e) after the reaction for 10 min, and (c, f) after reaction for 300 min. The bars represent 50 nm.

div.div:
High resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of the CuO samples after activation indicated that the disintegrated morphology was polycrystalline, composed of small domains in a size about 5 nm, with numerous interfaces and junctions in-between (
Figures
7
a–c). The fast Fourier transform (FFT) of the individual aggregates did not exhibit a particular pattern (
Figures
7
d and
S10
, Supporting Information). For the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles, although the crystallinity was seriously broken, neighboring domains were still intact enough to sustain the entire hollow shell structure (
Figures
7
e–g). The FFT pattern of the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles showed a blurred face-centered cubic pattern, revealing that the original single-crystalline Cu
2
O domains were not fully disintegrated (
Figures
7
h and
S11
, Supporting Information). These observations indicate that the initial morphology of copper oxide nanoparticles directly induced the formation of active structure, which were small domains in a few nm diameters, and eventually influenced catalytic performances. In fact, the branched CuO nanoparticles originally had small polycrystalline domains with high energy facets and grain boundaries in their morphology, which might cause a severe disintegration during the activation. On the contrary, the pristine cubic Cu
2
O particles were entirely single-crystalline covered with stable {100} surface facets, which could sustain original cubic frames even after the activation
(25)
(
Figure S10 and S11
, Supporting Information).

div.p:
Figure 7. Structural analysis of disintegrated catalyst morphology. HRTEM images of (a–c) branched CuO and (e–g) cube Cu
2
O nanoparticles and (d, h) FFT patterns of (c) and (f) respectively, after the activation. The bars represent 5 nm.

div.div:
The CuO nanoparticles maintained their morphology without substantial agglomeration after reaction for 12 h, which showed high stability due to the strong interaction with the conductive carbon materials (
Figures S9a–d
, Supporting Information). For the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles, it was interesting that the cube framework was still retained, despite a huge decrease in active surface area after the reaction, indicating the agglomeration within the individual framework (
Figures S9e–h
, Supporting Information). Some detachment of the copper catalyst from the electrode was also observed after the reaction.

div.h3: Electrochemical Active Surface Area and Local pH Effect
div.div:
The active structure induced by the branched CuO nanoparticles had an electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) much larger than that of the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles under identical metal loading. The ECSA of copper was measured using an underpotential deposition of lead on copper surface.
(34−37)
In the cyclic voltammogram, the branched CuO nanoparticles after activation showed a large maximum current at −0.33 V vs Ag/AgCl, corresponding to the ECSA of 3.49 cm
2
, whereas the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles had the ECSA of 1.71 cm
2
(
Figure S12a
and
S12b
, Supporting Information). After the reaction for 12 h, the ECSA of the branched nanoparticles decreased to 2.46 cm
2
, in good agreement with the slight decrease in the ethylene FE at the prolonged reaction progress (
Figure S12a
, Supporting Information). In the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles, the ECSA largely diminished to 0.17 cm
2
, which was only 10% from the original surface area, also corroborating sudden drop of the ethylene FE during the reaction (
Figure S12b
, Supporting Information). We also measured ECSAs by double-layer capacitance. The values were 54.9 cm
2
for branched CuO and 86.9 cm
2
for cubic Cu
2
O electrodes, which were dominated by the surface area of carbon materials, but not by the copper catalysts (
Figure S13
, Supporting Information).
(38)

Due to the highly active surface with large surface area and many interface and junctions between the small domains, the branched CuO nanoparticles exhibited superior surface activity for CO
2
RR. This led to the rapid consumption of protons from the electrolyte, increasing the local pH near the electrode surface. It was reported that the local pH could increase to 13 on the electrode–electrolyte boundary even when using a neutral electrolyte.
(39)
Such high local pH could suppress the formation of methane, but enhance carbon–carbon coupling of the intermediates to produce C
2
products,
(15,40,41)
leading to high FE for ethylene production. However, the high local pH also decreased CO
2
solubility and readily formed HCO
3
–
and CO
3
2–
ions in aqueous solution; therefore, the CO
2
RR rate was limited by the mass transfer of dissolved CO
2
.
(18)
As a result, the reaction rate was dependent upon the CO
2
flow rate. To prove this local pH effect, the CO
2
bubbling rate was varied from 10 to 60 min/cc during the reaction. When using the branched CuO nanoparticles, the FE of H
2
decreased from 49% to 37%, and the FE of C
2
products (mostly ethylene) was increased from 46% to 57% by increasing the CO
2
flow rate (
Figure S10c
, Supporting Information). The rapid supply of CO
2
could generate more ethylene than methane and other hydrogenation products. In contrast, the FE of H
2
increased with decrease in the C
2
products when using the cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles, due to the lower surface pH by CO
2
bubbling (
Figure S10d
, Supporting Information).

Strasser et al. also discussed the local pH effect using the variation of electrolyte concentration. In the lower concentration of bicarbonate, the ethylene production was dramatically enhanced, due to the increasing pH near the copper surface.
(15)
We observed the same phenomenon; under 0.1 M KHCO
3
solution, the FE of ethylene reached 53%, while the use of 0.5 M electrolyte dropped the maximum FE of ethylene to 36% at the same potential (
Figures
2
and
S2
, Supporting Information). These two experimental evidence supported that the high local pH is one of the important causes achieving high ethylene selectivity when using the branched CuO nanoparticles.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this work, we demonstrated that copper oxide nanoparticles on conductive carbon materials served as excellent electrocatalysts for CO
2
RR. Their selectivity for ethylene production was even superior to other thin-film based copper catalysts in neutral aqueous solutions. It was previously reported that the particle size,
(14)
surface structure,
(9)
and ensembles
(5)
of copper nanoparticles were critical factors for the selectivity of higher hydrocarbons such as C
2
and C
3
products. In the electrodeposited copper catalyst, sharp morphologies contributed only the catalytic reaction rate, but the presence of Cu
+
preferably generated ethylene.
(17)
Plasma-activated copper catalyst also exhibited the importance of Cu
+
species for selective ethylene production, but the surface structure was not the essential factor in catalytic activity.
(6)

In our work, however, the initial morphology of the branched or cubic nanoparticles was critical for eventual electrocatalytic performance. The branched morphology could generate highly active domains with high density of interfaces and junctions in-between, whereas the cubic particles did not form fully disintegrated morphology during activation. In terms of the surface composition, there was no difference between branched CuO and cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles after the activation. By surface characterization after CO
2
RR, Cu
+
was observed to be a major species in both nanoparticles, which was suggested as a critical composition for ethylene production.
(17,18)
In this aspect, the difference in morphology was more significant to distinguish the reactivity in our catalytic system. The large surface area and high local pH resulting from the active copper domains and their junctions induced high ethylene FE in neutral aqueous solution. It was mainly attributed that our particle-based catalysts had a uniform morphology of active species to readily observe morphology-dependent properties, whereas the thin film-based catalysts could not show.

Notably, the branched copper oxide catalyst generated only two products, ethylene (70% FE) and H
2
(30% FE) without byproducts such as CO, methane, formate, and ethanol, under the optimal reaction conditions. This result is very meaningful for practical applications in which the final products must be separated into pure substances. In the most of thin film-based copper catalysts, liquid products, particularly ethanol, were concomitantly produced with ethylene.
(6−11,17)
In contrast, the copper nanocubes produced hydrogen and ethylene with the small FE less than 5% for all other detectable liquid products.
(24)
It was also reported that ethanol was majorly produced at the high overpotentials when using copper nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped carbon spikes.
(8)
These observations revealed that the carbon support played a critical role to determine C
2
product selectivity. In our experiment, the carbon support without copper oxide nanoparticles only produced hydrogen, which could additionally increase the local pH during the reaction, leading to the formation of C
2
products. It was known that ethylene production from the *CH
2
CHO intermediate was more favorable by 0.2 eV than the formation toward ethanol.
(41)
We suppose that the strong interaction of electron-deficient carbon with copper may also facilitate the attack of hydrogen radical to carbon atom bonded to O of the intermediates, and lead to the pathway of ethylene production, but further studies are required. The high stability of our catalyst, enough to sustain ethylene FE higher than 65% for 12 h, also indicates the effective stabilization of active catalytic morphology by the carbon support.

We expect that the rational synthesis of active copper domain structure with more strongly bound carbon materials can additionally maximize the catalytic activity toward desired products with high sustainability, which would pave the way to approach commercial application of electrochemical CO
2
RR.

Electrocatalytic Conversion of Carbon Dioxide to Methane and Methanol on Transition Metal Surfaces

Fuels and industrial chems. that are conventionally derived from fossil resources could potentially be produced in a renewable, sustainable manner by an electrochem. process that operates at room temp. and atm. pressure, using only water, CO2, and electricity as inputs. To enable this technol., improved catalysts must be developed. Herein, trends are reported in the electrocatalytic conversion of CO2 on a broad group of seven transition metal surfaces: Au, Ag, Zn, Cu, Ni, Pt, and Fe. Contrary to conventional knowledge in the field, all metals studied are capable of producing methane or methanol. Reaction rates are quantified for these two products and catalyst activity and selectivity are described in the framework of CO binding energies for the different metals. While selectivity toward methane or methanol is low for most of these metals, the fact that they are all capable of producing these products, even at a low rate, is important new knowledge. This study reveals a richer surface chem. for transition metals than previously known and provides new insights to guide the development of improved CO2 conversion catalysts.

We report selective electrocatalytic redn. of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide on gold nanoparticles (NPs) in 0.5 M KHCO3 at 25 °C. Among monodisperse 4, 6, 8, and 10 nm NPs tested, the 8 nm Au NPs show the max. Faradaic efficiency (FE) (up to 90% at -0.67 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE). D. functional theory calcns. suggest that more edge sites (active for CO evolution) than corner sites (active for the competitive H2 evolution reaction) on the Au NP surface facilitates the stabilization of the redn. intermediates, such as COOH*, and the formation of CO. This mechanism is further supported by the fact that Au NPs embedded in a matrix of butyl-3-methyl-imid-azolium hexafluorophosphate for more efficient COOH* stabilization exhibit even higher reaction activity (3 A/g mass activity) and selectivity (97% FE) at -0.52 V (vs RHE). The work demonstrates the great potentials of using monodisperse Au NPs to optimize the available reaction intermediate binding sites for efficient and selective electrocatalytic redn. of CO2 to CO.

With rising levels of CO2 in our atm., technologies capable of converting CO2 into useful products have become more valuable. The field of electrochem. CO2 redn. is reviewed here, with sections on mechanism, formate (formic acid) prodn., carbon monoxide prodn., redn. to higher products (methanol, methane, etc.), use of flow cells, high pressure approaches, mol. catalysts, non-aq. electrolytes, and solid oxide electrolysis cells. These diverse approaches to electrochem. CO2 redn. are compared and contrasted, emphasizing potential processes that would be feasible for large-scale use. Although the focus is on recent reports, highlights of older reports are also included due to their important contributions to the field, particularly for high-rate electrolysis.

Selective electrochem. redn. of CO2 is one of the most sought-after processes because of the potential to convert a harmful greenhouse gas to a useful chem. Immobilized Ag nanoparticles supported on C exhibit enhanced faradaic efficiency and a lower overpotential for selective redn. of CO2 to CO. These electrocatalysts were synthesized directly on the C support by a facile 1-pot method using a cysteamine anchoring agent resulting in controlled monodispersed particle sizes. These synthesized Ag/C electrodes showed improved activities, specifically decrease of the overpotential by 300 mV at 1 mA/cm2, and 4-fold enhanced CO faradaic efficiency at -0.75 V vs. RHE with the optimal particle size of 5 nm compared to polycryst. Ag foil. DFT calcns. enlightened that the specific interaction between Ag nanoparticle and the anchoring agents modified the catalyst surface to have a selectively higher affinity to the intermediate COOH over CO, which effectively lowers the overpotential.

Direct conversion of carbon dioxide to multicarbon products remains as a grand challenge in electrochem. CO2 redn. Various forms of oxidized copper have been demonstrated as electrocatalysts that still require large overpotentials. Here, we show that an ensemble of Cu nanoparticles (NPs) enables selective formation of C2-C3 products at low overpotentials. Densely packed Cu NP ensembles underwent structural transformation during electrolysis into electrocatalytically active cube-like particles intermixed with smaller nanoparticles. Ethylene, ethanol, and n-propanol are the major C2-C3 products with onset potential at -0.53 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) and C2-C3 faradaic efficiency (FE) reaching 50% at only -0.75 V. Thus, the catalyst exhibits selective generation of C2-C3 hydrocarbons and oxygenates at considerably lowered overpotentials in neutral pH aq. media. In addn., this approach suggests new opportunities in realizing multicarbon product formation from CO2, where the majority of efforts has been to use oxidized copper-based materials. Robust catalytic performance is demonstrated by 10 h of stable operation with C2-C3 c.d. 10 mA/cm2 (at -0.75 V), rendering it attractive for solar-to-fuel applications. Tafel anal. suggests reductive CO coupling as a rate detg. step for C2 products, while n-propanol (C3) prodn. seems to have a discrete pathway.

There is an urgent need to develop technologies that use renewable energy to convert waste products such as carbon dioxide into hydrocarbon fuels. Carbon dioxide can be electrochem. reduced to hydrocarbons over copper catalysts, although higher efficiency is required. We have developed oxidized copper catalysts displaying lower over potentials for carbon dioxide electroredn. and record selectivity towards ethylene (60%) through facile and tunable plasma treatments. Herein we provide insight into the improved performance of these catalysts by combining electrochem. measurements with microscopic and spectroscopic characterization techniques. Operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy and cross-sectional scanning transmission electron microscopy show that copper oxides are surprisingly resistant to redn. and copper+ species remain on the surface during the reaction. Our results demonstrate that the roughness of oxide-derived copper catalysts plays only a partial role in detg. the catalytic performance, while the presence of copper+ is key for lowering the onset potential and enhancing ethylene selectivity.

Modified Cu electrodes were prepd. by annealing Cu foil in air and electrochem. reducing the resulting Cu2O layers. The CO2 redn. activities of these electrodes exhibited a strong dependence on the initial thickness of the Cu2O layer. Thin Cu2O layers formed by annealing at 130° resulted in electrodes whose activities were indistinguishable from those of polycryst. Cu. In contrast, Cu2O layers formed at 500° that were ≥ ∼3 μm thick resulted in electrodes that exhibited large roughness factors and required 0.5 V less overpotential than polycryst. Cu to reduce CO2 at a higher rate than H2O. The combination of these features resulted in CO2 redn. geometric current densities >1 mA/cm2 at overpotentials <0.4 V, a higher level of activity than all previously reported metal electrodes evaluated under comparable conditions. Also, the activity of the modified electrodes was stable over several hours, whereas a polycryst. Cu electrode exhibited deactivation within 1 h under identical conditions. The electrodes described here may be particularly useful for elucidating the structural properties of Cu that det. the distribution between CO2 and H2O redn. and provide a promising lead for the development of practical catalysts for electrolytic fuel synthesis.

Ren, Dan; Deng, Yilin; Handoko, Albertus Denny; Chen, Chung Shou; Malkhandi, Souradip; Yeo, Boon Siang

The selective electroredn. of carbon dioxide to C2 compds. (ethylene and ethanol) on copper(I) oxide films has been investigated at various electrochem. potentials. Aq. 0.1 M KHCO3 was used as electrolyte. A remarkable finding is that the faradic yields of ethylene and ethanol can be systematically tuned by changing the thickness of the deposited overlayers. Films 1.7-3.6 μm thick exhibited the best selectivity for these C2 compds. at -0.99 V vs RHE, with faradic efficiencies (FE) of 34-39% for ethylene and 9-16% for ethanol. Less than 1% methane was formed. A high C2H4/CH4 products' ratio of up to ∼100 could be achieved. SEM, X-ray diffraction, and in situ Raman spectroscopy revealed that the Cu2O films reduced rapidly and remained as metallic Cu0 particles during the CO2 redn. The selectivity trends exhibited by the catalysts during CO2 redn. in phosphate buffer, and KHCO3 electrolytes suggest that an increase in local pH at the surface of the electrode is not the only factor in enhancing the formation of C2 products. An optimized surface population of edges and steps on the catalyst is also necessary to facilitate the dissocn. of CO2 and the dimerization of the pertinent CHxO intermediates to ethylene and ethanol.

We report new insights into the electrochem. redn. of CO2 on a metallic copper surface, enabled by the development of an exptl. methodol. with unprecedented sensitivity for the identification and quantification of CO2 electroredn. products. This involves a custom electrochem. cell designed to maximize product concns. coupled to gas chromatog. and NMR for the identification and quantification of gas and liq. products, resp. We studied copper across a range of potentials and obsd. a total of 16 different CO2 redn. products, five of which are reported here for the first time, thus providing the most complete view of the reaction chem. reported to date. Taking into account the chem. identities of the wide range of C1-C3 products generated and the potential-dependence of their turnover frequencies, mechanistic information is deduced. We discuss a scheme for the formation of multi-carbon products involving enol-like surface intermediates as a possible pathway, accounting for the obsd. selectivity for eleven distinct C2+ oxygenated products including aldehydes, ketones, alcs., and carboxylic acids.

Developing catalytic systems with high efficiency and selectivity is a fundamental issue for photochemical carbon dioxide conversion. In particular, rigorous control of the structure and morphology of photocatalysts is decisive for catalytic performance. Here, we report the synthesis of zinc oxide-copper(I) oxide hybrid nanoparticles as colloidal forms bearing copper(I) oxide nanocubes bound to zinc oxide spherical cores. The zinc oxide-copper(I) oxide nanoparticles behave as photocatalysts for the direct conversion of carbon dioxide to methane in an aqueous medium, under ambient pressure and temperature. The catalysts produce methane with an activity of 1080 μmol gcat(-1) h(-1), a quantum yield of 1.5% and a selectivity for methane of >99%. The catalytic ability of the zinc oxide-copper(I) oxide hybrid catalyst is attributed to excellent band alignment of the zinc-oxide and copper(I) oxide domains, few surface defects which reduce defect-induced charge recombination and enhance electron transfer to the reagents, and a high-surface area colloidal morphology.

The activity and selectivity of Cu during the CO2 electrochem. redn. can be tuned by changing the concn. of the bicarbonate electrolyte. Comparing the abs. formation rate and faradaic selectivity of H2, CH4, CO, and C2H4 as a function of the applied electrode potential, variations in the bulk buffer capacities of the electrolyte have substantial impact on abs. product formation rates and relative faradaic selectivity. High concns. of bicarbonate improve the overall faradaic CO2 electroredn. activity, largely due to higher abs. formation rates of H2 and CH4. In lower-concd. bicarbonate electrolytes with their lower overall activity, the selectivity toward ethylene was drastically enhanced. Following earlier theor. work, the authors hypothesize the pH near the Cu electrode interface to largely account for the obsd. effects: dild. KHCO3 solns. allow for more alk. local pH values during CO2 electroredn. The authors' study highlights the controlling role of the interfacial pH on the product distribution during CO2 redn. over a wide electrode potential range.

Carbon dioxide (CO2) electroredn. could provide a useful source of ethylene, but low conversion efficiency, low prodn. rates, and low catalyst stability limit current systems. Here we report that a copper electrocatalyst at an abrupt reaction interface in an alk. electrolyte reduces CO2 to ethylene with 70% faradaic efficiency at a potential of -0.55 V vs. a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Hydroxide ions on or near the copper surface lower the CO2 redn. and carbon monoxide (CO)-CO coupling activation energy barriers; as a result, onset of ethylene evolution at -0.165 V vs. an RHE in 10 M potassium hydroxide occurs almost simultaneously with CO prodn. Operational stability was enhanced via the introduction of a polymer-based gas diffusion layer that sandwiches the reaction interface between sep. hydrophobic and conductive supports, providing const. ethylene selectivity for an initial 150 operating hours.

Oxide-derived Cu (OD-Cu) electrodes exhibit higher activity than pristine Cu during the CO2 redn. reaction (CO2RR) and higher selectivity towards ethylene. The presence of residual subsurface O in OD-Cu probably is responsible for such improvements, although its stability under the reductive CO2RR conditions remains unclear. This work sheds light on the nature and stability of subsurface O. The authors' spectroscopic results show that O is primarily concd. in an amorphous 1-2 nm thick layer within the Cu subsurface, confirming that subsurface O is stable during CO2RR for up to 1 h at -1.15 V vs. RHE. Besides, it is assocd. with a high d. of defects in the OD-Cu structure. Probably both low-coordination of the amorphous OD-Cu surface and the presence of subsurface O that withdraws charge from the Cu sp.- and d-bands might selectively enhance the binding energy of CO.

Oxide-derived (OD) Cu catalysts have high selectivity towards the formation of multi-C products (C2/C3) for aq. electrochem. CO2 redn. (CO2R). It has been proposed that a large fraction of the initial oxide can be surprisingly resistant to redn., and these residual oxides play a crucial catalytic role. The stability of residual oxides was studied by synthesizing 18O-enriched OD Cu catalysts and testing them for CO2R. These catalysts maintain a high selectivity towards C2/C3 products (∼60%) for ≤5 h in 0.1M KHCO3 at -1.0 V vs. RHE. However, secondary-ion mass spectrometry measurements show that only a small fraction (<1%) of the original 18O content remains, showing that residual oxides are not present in significant amts. during CO2R. We show that OD Cu can reoxidize rapidly, which could compromise the accuracy of ex situ methods for detg. the true oxygen content.

It has recently been proposed that subsurface O is crucial for the adsorption and subsequent electroredn. of CO2 on Cu. Using d. functional theory, the authors have studied the stability and diffusion of subsurface O in single crystals of Cu exposing (111) and (100) facets. O is at least 1.5 eV more stable on the surface than beneath it for both crystal orientations; interstitial sites are too small to accommodate O. The rate of at. O diffusion from one layer below a Cu(111) surface to the surface is 5 × 103 s-1. O can survive longer in deeper layers, but it does not promote CO2 adsorption there. Diffusion of subsurface O is easier to the less-dense Cu(100) surface, even from lower layers (rate ≈ 1 × 107 s-1). Once the applied voltage and dispersion forces are properly modeled, subsurface O is unnecessary for CO2 adsorption on Cu.

Potential-induced nanoclustering of metallic catalysts during electrochemical CO2 reduction
Huang Jianfeng; Loiudice Anna; De Gregorio Gian Luca; Buonsanti Raffaella; Hormann Nicolas; Andreussi Oliviero; Marzari Nicola; Oveisi Emad; Andreussi Oliviero
Nature communications
(
2018

In catalysis science stability is as crucial as activity and selectivity. Understanding the degradation pathways occurring during operation and developing mitigation strategies will eventually improve catalyst design, thus facilitating the translation of basic science to technological applications. Herein, we reveal the unique and general degradation mechanism of metallic nanocatalysts during electrochemical CO2 reduction, exemplified by different sized copper nanocubes. We follow their morphological evolution during operation and correlate it with the electrocatalytic performance. In contrast with the most common coalescence and dissolution/precipitation mechanisms, we find a potential-driven nanoclustering to be the predominant degradation pathway. Grand-potential density functional theory calculations confirm the role of the negative potential applied to reduce CO2 as the main driving force for the clustering. This study offers a novel outlook on future investigations of stability and degradation reaction mechanisms of nanocatalysts in electrochemical CO2 reduction and, more generally, in electroreduction reactions.

Stable and selective electrochem. redn. of carbon dioxide to ethylene was achieved using copper mesocrystal catalysts in 0.1 M KHCO3. The Cu mesocrystal catalysts were facilely derived by the in situ redn. of a thin CuCl film during the first 200 s of the CO2 electroredn. process. At -0.99 V vs. RHE, the Faradaic efficiency of ethylene formation using these Cu mesocrystals was ∼18× larger than that of methane and forms up to 81% of the total carbonaceous products. Control CO2 redn. expts. show that this selectivity towards C2H4 formation could not be replicated by using regular copper nanoparticles formed by pulse electrodeposition. High resoln. transmission electron microscopy reveals the presence of both (100)Cu facets and at. steps in the Cu mesocrystals which we assign as active sites in catalyzing the redn. of CO2 to C2H4. CO adsorption measurements suggest that the remarkable C2H4 selectivity could be attributed to the greater propensity of CO adsorption on Cu mesocrystals than on other types of Cu surfaces. The Cu mesocrystals remained active and selective towards C2H4 formation for longer than six hours. This is an important and industrially relevant feature missing from many reported Cu-based CO2 redn. catalysts.

Time Evolution of the Wettability of Supported Graphene under Ambient Air Exposure
Aria, Adrianus I.; Kidambi, Piran R.; Weatherup, Robert S.; Xiao, Long; Williams, John A.; Hofmann, Stephan
Journal of Physical Chemistry C
(
2016
),
120
(
4
),
2215-2224
CODEN:
JPCCCK
; ISSN:
1932-7447
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The wettability of graphene is both fundamental and crucial for interfacing in most applications, but a detailed understanding of its time evolution remains elusive. Here we systematically investigate the wettability of metal-supported, chem. vapor deposited graphene films as a function of ambient air exposure time using water and various other test liqs. with widely different surface tensions. The wettability of graphene is not const., but varies with substrate interactions and air exposure time. The substrate interactions affect the initial graphene wettability, where, for instance, water contact angles of ∼85 and ∼61° were measured for Ni and Cu supported graphene, resp., after just minutes of air exposure. Anal. of the surface free energy components indicates that the substrate interactions strongly influence the Lewis acid-base component of supported graphene, which is considerably weaker for Ni supported graphene than for Cu supported graphene, suggesting that the classical van der Waals interaction theory alone is insufficient to describe the wettability of graphene. For prolonged air exposure, the effect of physisorption of airborne contaminants becomes increasingly dominant, resulting in an increase of water contact angle that follows a universal linear-logarithmic relationship with exposure time, until satg. at a max. value of 92-98°. The adsorbed contaminants render all supported graphene samples increasingly nonpolar, although their total surface free energy decreases only by 10-16% to about 37-41 mJ/m2. Our finding shows that failure to account for the air exposure time may lead to widely different wettability values and contradicting arguments about the wetting transparency of graphene.

Metal org. chem. vapor deposition is carefully optimized for the growth of pure CuCrO2 delafossite coatings on glass substrates. The pulsed direct liq. delivery is demonstrated to be an efficient process technol. for the controlled supply of the precursor soln. in the evapn. chamber, which is one of the main process parameters to tailor the thin-film properties. We investigated the influence of the precursor concn. ratio Cu(thd)2 (bis[2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-3,5-heptanedionato]copper(II)) and Cr(thd)3 (tris[2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-3,5-heptanedionato]chromium(III)) on the crystal structure, morphol. and elec. cond., at a reduced temp. of 370°. We observe for a low ratio, a pure delafossite phase with a const. Cu-poor/Cr-rich chem. compn., while at a high ratio a mixt. of copper oxides and CuCrO2 was found. The as-grown 140 nm-thick pure delafossite films exhibit an exceptional high elec. cond. for a non-intentionally doped CuCrO2, 17 S cm-1, and a near 50% transparency in the visible spectral range.

Electrodeposition mechanism of Pb on polycryst. Cu from a perchlorate soln. in the presence of Cl- was investigated. Electrochem. quartz crystal microbalance data including frequency and resistance were simultaneously recorded with cyclic voltammograms and current transients. The change of frequency and resistance shows that a rigid bulk film forms at the potentials more neg. than -0.52 V SCE, exhibiting the overpotential deposits of Pb (OPD). However, at the potentials ranging from -0.38 to -0.43 V SCE, a monolayer of Pb as the underpotential deposit of Pb (UPD) is formed. The measured real mass of the OPD of Pb compared to the charge passed through the cell elucidates the formation of Pb (II). The magnitude of the applied overpotential has considerable effect on the growth of the OPD of Pb. The Pb OPDs formed at the lower overpotentials (or applied potentials in a range of -0.54 to -0.58 V SCE) show slight pos. deviation of the electrochem. equiv. (M/n) of Pb (II). This evidence is ascribed to the possible incorporation of adsorbed/alloyed elements like chlorine in the film compn. At the higher overpotentials (or applied potentials of neg. than -0.58 V SCE), the ratio starts to decrease, mainly due to the hydrogen evolution assocd. with the possible morphol. change of deposit. The nucleation and growth of Pb OPD can be described with the instantaneous mechanism based on Scharifker-Hills prediction with nondimensional plots.

The adsorption behavior of Pb2+ on Cu(111) was studied in 0.5M NaClO4 at pH 3.5 and 0.5, using semi-infinite and twin-electrode thin layer voltammetry (TTL) as well as potential step excitation techniques. The voltammetric features and the charge stoichiometry of the adsorption/desorption process are affected markedly by the pH of the electrolyte and by the prepolarization conditions. The 2 dimensional-nucleative adsorbate formation is obsd. at pH ≥1.5 under certain prepolarization conditions and occurs concurrently with the desorption of a removable O coverage, thus suggesting a pit-formation process. The results are discussed in terms of participation of O species in the overall adsorption/desorption mechanism.

Real surface area measurements in electrochemistry

A review with 146 refs. is given. Electrode reaction rates and most double layer parameters are extensive quantities and have to be referred to the unit areas of the interface. Knowledge of the real surface area of electrodes is therefore needed. Comparison of exptl. data with theories or of exptl. results for different materials and/or from different labs. to each other is phys. groundless without normalization to unit real area of the electrode surface. Different methods have been proposed to normalize exptl. data specifically with solid electrodes. Some of them are not sufficiently justified from a phys. point of view. A few of them are definitely questionable. The purpose of this document is to scrutinize the basis on which the various methods and approaches rest, to assess their relevance to the specific electrochem. situations and, as far as possible, their abs. reliability. '. Methods and approaches are applicable to (1) liq. electrodes; (2) polycryst. and single crystal face solids; (3) supported, compressed and disperse powders. The applicability of the various techniques to each specific case is to be verified. After an introductory discussion of the "concept" of real surface areas, 15 methods, 11 applied in situ and 4 ex situ, are scrutinized. For each of them, after a description of the principles on which it is based, limitations are discussed and recommendations are given.

Activities of Cu nanoparticles supported on C black (VC), single-wall C nanotubes (SWNTs), and Ketjen Black (KB) toward CO2 electroredn. to hydrocarbons (CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6) are evaluated using a sealed rotating disk electrode (RDE) setup coupled to a gas chromatograph (GC). Thin films of supported Cu catalysts are deposited on RDE tips following a procedure well-established in the fuel cell community. Lead (Pb) underpotential deposition (UPD) was used to det. the electrochem. surface area (ECSA) of thin films of 40% Cu/VC, 20% Cu/SWNT, 50% Cu/KB, and com. 20% Cu/VC catalysts on glassy C electrodes. Faradaic efficiencies of four C-supported Cu catalysts toward CO2 electroredn. to hydrocarbons are compared to that of electrodeposited smooth Cu films. For all the catalysts studied, the only hydrocarbons detected by GC are CH4 and C2H4. The Cu nanoparticles are more active toward C2H4 generation vs. electrodeposited smooth Cu films. For the supported Cu nanocatalysts, the ratio of C2H4/CH4 faradaic efficiencies is believed to be a function of particle size, as higher ratios are obsd. for smaller Cu nanoparticles. This is likely due to an increase in the fraction of under-coordinated sites, such as corners, edges, and defects, as the nanoparticles become smaller.

In this study, we fabricated nitrogen-enriched multimodal porous carbons (NMPCs) from a self-assembled inclusion complex induced by the interaction between urea hydrates as host mols. and cellulose mols. as guest mols. for supercapacitors. The novel carbon material could be obtained on a gram-scale due to the simple synthetic process and widely available precursor, cellulose, from markets and had a three-dimensionally interconnected structure, as well as multimodal porous characteristics and a large amt. of nitrogen (10.5 wt%). The NMPCs exhibited a high capacitance due to the pseudocapacitive behaviors of the nitrogen groups, and their multimodal structure facilitated the ideal capacitive behavior as a result of the fast ionic motion. Moreover, the NMPCs exhibited good cycle stability and a high degree of reversibility in repetitive charge/discharge cycling.

A review. The electrochem. redn. of CO2 has gained significant interest recently as it has the potential to trigger a sustainable solar-fuel-based economy. In this Perspective, we highlight several heterogeneous and mol. electrocatalysts for the redn. of CO2 and discuss the reaction pathways through which they form various products. Among those, copper is a unique catalyst as it yields hydrocarbon products, mostly methane, ethylene, and ethanol, with acceptable efficiencies. As a result, substantial effort has been invested to det. the special catalytic properties of copper and to elucidate the mechanism through which hydrocarbons are formed. These mechanistic insights, together with mechanistic insights of CO2 redn. on other metals and mol. complexes, can provide crucial guidelines for the design of future catalyst materials able to efficiently and selectively reduce CO2 to useful products.

2
O nanoparticles. TEM images of (insets) nanoparticles and their hybrids with Ketjen black using (b) cubic Cu
2
O and (c) branched CuO. XRD spectra of the hybrids using (d) cubic Cu
2
O and (e) branched CuO nanoparticles. The bars represent 100 nm.

Figure 2. Electrocatalytic profiles of copper oxide nanoparticles. (a, b) FEs and (c, d) current densities at various applied potentials of H
2
(red), ethylene (blue), CO (orange), and methane (green) using (a, c) branched CuO and (b, d) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles as electrocatalysts.

Figure 3. Temporal change of electrochemical CO
2
RR. (a, b) Faradaic efficiency and (c, d) current density changes with the time progress using (a, c) branched CuO and (b, d) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles as electrocatalysts for 12 h. The lines represent H
2
(red), ethylene (blue), CO (orange), methane (green), ethane (pink), and total (black), respectively.

Figure 4. Characterization of surface copper species. X-ray photoelectron spectra of branched CuO and cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles in the catalyst electrodes before and after the activation in the regions of (a) Cu 2p and (b) Auger Cu LMM. The dotted lines represent the binding energies of Cu(0), Cu
+
, and Cu
2+
species according to the literature.
(30,31)

Figure 5. XANES spectra of (a) branched CuO and (b) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles in the catalyst electrodes ex situ before and after the activation.

Figure 6. Temporal morphology change during electrochemical CO
2
RR. TEM images of (a–c) branched CuO and (d–f) cubic Cu
2
O nanoparticles (a, d) after the activation, (b, e) after the reaction for 10 min, and (c, f) after reaction for 300 min. The bars represent 50 nm.

Figure 7. Structural analysis of disintegrated catalyst morphology. HRTEM images of (a–c) branched CuO and (e–g) cube Cu
2
O nanoparticles and (d, h) FFT patterns of (c) and (f) respectively, after the activation. The bars represent 5 nm.

Electrocatalytic Conversion of Carbon Dioxide to Methane and Methanol on Transition Metal Surfaces
Kuhl, Kendra P.; Hatsukade, Toru; Cave, Etosha R.; Abram, David N.; Kibsgaard, Jakob; Jaramillo, Thomas F.

Fuels and industrial chems. that are conventionally derived from fossil resources could potentially be produced in a renewable, sustainable manner by an electrochem. process that operates at room temp. and atm. pressure, using only water, CO2, and electricity as inputs. To enable this technol., improved catalysts must be developed. Herein, trends are reported in the electrocatalytic conversion of CO2 on a broad group of seven transition metal surfaces: Au, Ag, Zn, Cu, Ni, Pt, and Fe. Contrary to conventional knowledge in the field, all metals studied are capable of producing methane or methanol. Reaction rates are quantified for these two products and catalyst activity and selectivity are described in the framework of CO binding energies for the different metals. While selectivity toward methane or methanol is low for most of these metals, the fact that they are all capable of producing these products, even at a low rate, is important new knowledge. This study reveals a richer surface chem. for transition metals than previously known and provides new insights to guide the development of improved CO2 conversion catalysts.

We report selective electrocatalytic redn. of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide on gold nanoparticles (NPs) in 0.5 M KHCO3 at 25 °C. Among monodisperse 4, 6, 8, and 10 nm NPs tested, the 8 nm Au NPs show the max. Faradaic efficiency (FE) (up to 90% at -0.67 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE). D. functional theory calcns. suggest that more edge sites (active for CO evolution) than corner sites (active for the competitive H2 evolution reaction) on the Au NP surface facilitates the stabilization of the redn. intermediates, such as COOH*, and the formation of CO. This mechanism is further supported by the fact that Au NPs embedded in a matrix of butyl-3-methyl-imid-azolium hexafluorophosphate for more efficient COOH* stabilization exhibit even higher reaction activity (3 A/g mass activity) and selectivity (97% FE) at -0.52 V (vs RHE). The work demonstrates the great potentials of using monodisperse Au NPs to optimize the available reaction intermediate binding sites for efficient and selective electrocatalytic redn. of CO2 to CO.

With rising levels of CO2 in our atm., technologies capable of converting CO2 into useful products have become more valuable. The field of electrochem. CO2 redn. is reviewed here, with sections on mechanism, formate (formic acid) prodn., carbon monoxide prodn., redn. to higher products (methanol, methane, etc.), use of flow cells, high pressure approaches, mol. catalysts, non-aq. electrolytes, and solid oxide electrolysis cells. These diverse approaches to electrochem. CO2 redn. are compared and contrasted, emphasizing potential processes that would be feasible for large-scale use. Although the focus is on recent reports, highlights of older reports are also included due to their important contributions to the field, particularly for high-rate electrolysis.

Selective electrochem. redn. of CO2 is one of the most sought-after processes because of the potential to convert a harmful greenhouse gas to a useful chem. Immobilized Ag nanoparticles supported on C exhibit enhanced faradaic efficiency and a lower overpotential for selective redn. of CO2 to CO. These electrocatalysts were synthesized directly on the C support by a facile 1-pot method using a cysteamine anchoring agent resulting in controlled monodispersed particle sizes. These synthesized Ag/C electrodes showed improved activities, specifically decrease of the overpotential by 300 mV at 1 mA/cm2, and 4-fold enhanced CO faradaic efficiency at -0.75 V vs. RHE with the optimal particle size of 5 nm compared to polycryst. Ag foil. DFT calcns. enlightened that the specific interaction between Ag nanoparticle and the anchoring agents modified the catalyst surface to have a selectively higher affinity to the intermediate COOH over CO, which effectively lowers the overpotential.

Kim, Dohyung; Kley, Christopher S.; Li, Yifan; Yang, Peidong

Direct conversion of carbon dioxide to multicarbon products remains as a grand challenge in electrochem. CO2 redn. Various forms of oxidized copper have been demonstrated as electrocatalysts that still require large overpotentials. Here, we show that an ensemble of Cu nanoparticles (NPs) enables selective formation of C2-C3 products at low overpotentials. Densely packed Cu NP ensembles underwent structural transformation during electrolysis into electrocatalytically active cube-like particles intermixed with smaller nanoparticles. Ethylene, ethanol, and n-propanol are the major C2-C3 products with onset potential at -0.53 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) and C2-C3 faradaic efficiency (FE) reaching 50% at only -0.75 V. Thus, the catalyst exhibits selective generation of C2-C3 hydrocarbons and oxygenates at considerably lowered overpotentials in neutral pH aq. media. In addn., this approach suggests new opportunities in realizing multicarbon product formation from CO2, where the majority of efforts has been to use oxidized copper-based materials. Robust catalytic performance is demonstrated by 10 h of stable operation with C2-C3 c.d. 10 mA/cm2 (at -0.75 V), rendering it attractive for solar-to-fuel applications. Tafel anal. suggests reductive CO coupling as a rate detg. step for C2 products, while n-propanol (C3) prodn. seems to have a discrete pathway.

There is an urgent need to develop technologies that use renewable energy to convert waste products such as carbon dioxide into hydrocarbon fuels. Carbon dioxide can be electrochem. reduced to hydrocarbons over copper catalysts, although higher efficiency is required. We have developed oxidized copper catalysts displaying lower over potentials for carbon dioxide electroredn. and record selectivity towards ethylene (60%) through facile and tunable plasma treatments. Herein we provide insight into the improved performance of these catalysts by combining electrochem. measurements with microscopic and spectroscopic characterization techniques. Operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy and cross-sectional scanning transmission electron microscopy show that copper oxides are surprisingly resistant to redn. and copper+ species remain on the surface during the reaction. Our results demonstrate that the roughness of oxide-derived copper catalysts plays only a partial role in detg. the catalytic performance, while the presence of copper+ is key for lowering the onset potential and enhancing ethylene selectivity.

Modified Cu electrodes were prepd. by annealing Cu foil in air and electrochem. reducing the resulting Cu2O layers. The CO2 redn. activities of these electrodes exhibited a strong dependence on the initial thickness of the Cu2O layer. Thin Cu2O layers formed by annealing at 130° resulted in electrodes whose activities were indistinguishable from those of polycryst. Cu. In contrast, Cu2O layers formed at 500° that were ≥ ∼3 μm thick resulted in electrodes that exhibited large roughness factors and required 0.5 V less overpotential than polycryst. Cu to reduce CO2 at a higher rate than H2O. The combination of these features resulted in CO2 redn. geometric current densities >1 mA/cm2 at overpotentials <0.4 V, a higher level of activity than all previously reported metal electrodes evaluated under comparable conditions. Also, the activity of the modified electrodes was stable over several hours, whereas a polycryst. Cu electrode exhibited deactivation within 1 h under identical conditions. The electrodes described here may be particularly useful for elucidating the structural properties of Cu that det. the distribution between CO2 and H2O redn. and provide a promising lead for the development of practical catalysts for electrolytic fuel synthesis.

Ren, Dan; Deng, Yilin; Handoko, Albertus Denny; Chen, Chung Shou; Malkhandi, Souradip; Yeo, Boon Siang

American Chemical Society

The selective electroredn. of carbon dioxide to C2 compds. (ethylene and ethanol) on copper(I) oxide films has been investigated at various electrochem. potentials. Aq. 0.1 M KHCO3 was used as electrolyte. A remarkable finding is that the faradic yields of ethylene and ethanol can be systematically tuned by changing the thickness of the deposited overlayers. Films 1.7-3.6 μm thick exhibited the best selectivity for these C2 compds. at -0.99 V vs RHE, with faradic efficiencies (FE) of 34-39% for ethylene and 9-16% for ethanol. Less than 1% methane was formed. A high C2H4/CH4 products' ratio of up to ∼100 could be achieved. SEM, X-ray diffraction, and in situ Raman spectroscopy revealed that the Cu2O films reduced rapidly and remained as metallic Cu0 particles during the CO2 redn. The selectivity trends exhibited by the catalysts during CO2 redn. in phosphate buffer, and KHCO3 electrolytes suggest that an increase in local pH at the surface of the electrode is not the only factor in enhancing the formation of C2 products. An optimized surface population of edges and steps on the catalyst is also necessary to facilitate the dissocn. of CO2 and the dimerization of the pertinent CHxO intermediates to ethylene and ethanol.

We report new insights into the electrochem. redn. of CO2 on a metallic copper surface, enabled by the development of an exptl. methodol. with unprecedented sensitivity for the identification and quantification of CO2 electroredn. products. This involves a custom electrochem. cell designed to maximize product concns. coupled to gas chromatog. and NMR for the identification and quantification of gas and liq. products, resp. We studied copper across a range of potentials and obsd. a total of 16 different CO2 redn. products, five of which are reported here for the first time, thus providing the most complete view of the reaction chem. reported to date. Taking into account the chem. identities of the wide range of C1-C3 products generated and the potential-dependence of their turnover frequencies, mechanistic information is deduced. We discuss a scheme for the formation of multi-carbon products involving enol-like surface intermediates as a possible pathway, accounting for the obsd. selectivity for eleven distinct C2+ oxygenated products including aldehydes, ketones, alcs., and carboxylic acids.

The direct redn. of CO2 to CH3OH is known to occur at several types of electrocatalysts including oxidized Cu electrodes. In this work, the yield behavior of an electrodeposited cuprous oxide thin film was examd. and relationships between surface chem. and reaction behavior relative to air-oxidized and anodized Cu electrodes were explored. CH3OH yields (43 μmol cm-2 h-1) and Faradaic efficiencies (38%) obsd. at cuprous oxide electrodes were remarkably higher than air-oxidized or anodized Cu electrodes suggesting Cu(I) species may play a crit. role in selectivity to CH3OH. Yield behavior is discussed in comparison with photoelectrochem. and hydrogenation reactions where the improved stability of Cu(I) species may allow continuous CH3OH generation.

Colloidal zinc oxide-copper(I) oxide nanocatalysts for selective aqueous photocatalytic carbon dioxide conversion into methane
Bae Kyung-Lyul; Kim Jinmo; Lim Chan Kyu; Song Hyunjoon; Nam Ki Min
Nature communications
(
2017
),

.
Developing catalytic systems with high efficiency and selectivity is a fundamental issue for photochemical carbon dioxide conversion. In particular, rigorous control of the structure and morphology of photocatalysts is decisive for catalytic performance. Here, we report the synthesis of zinc oxide-copper(I) oxide hybrid nanoparticles as colloidal forms bearing copper(I) oxide nanocubes bound to zinc oxide spherical cores. The zinc oxide-copper(I) oxide nanoparticles behave as photocatalysts for the direct conversion of carbon dioxide to methane in an aqueous medium, under ambient pressure and temperature. The catalysts produce methane with an activity of 1080 μmol gcat(-1) h(-1), a quantum yield of 1.5% and a selectivity for methane of >99%. The catalytic ability of the zinc oxide-copper(I) oxide hybrid catalyst is attributed to excellent band alignment of the zinc-oxide and copper(I) oxide domains, few surface defects which reduce defect-induced charge recombination and enhance electron transfer to the reagents, and a high-surface area colloidal morphology.

The activity and selectivity of Cu during the CO2 electrochem. redn. can be tuned by changing the concn. of the bicarbonate electrolyte. Comparing the abs. formation rate and faradaic selectivity of H2, CH4, CO, and C2H4 as a function of the applied electrode potential, variations in the bulk buffer capacities of the electrolyte have substantial impact on abs. product formation rates and relative faradaic selectivity. High concns. of bicarbonate improve the overall faradaic CO2 electroredn. activity, largely due to higher abs. formation rates of H2 and CH4. In lower-concd. bicarbonate electrolytes with their lower overall activity, the selectivity toward ethylene was drastically enhanced. Following earlier theor. work, the authors hypothesize the pH near the Cu electrode interface to largely account for the obsd. effects: dild. KHCO3 solns. allow for more alk. local pH values during CO2 electroredn. The authors' study highlights the controlling role of the interfacial pH on the product distribution during CO2 redn. over a wide electrode potential range.

Carbon dioxide (CO2) electroredn. could provide a useful source of ethylene, but low conversion efficiency, low prodn. rates, and low catalyst stability limit current systems. Here we report that a copper electrocatalyst at an abrupt reaction interface in an alk. electrolyte reduces CO2 to ethylene with 70% faradaic efficiency at a potential of -0.55 V vs. a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Hydroxide ions on or near the copper surface lower the CO2 redn. and carbon monoxide (CO)-CO coupling activation energy barriers; as a result, onset of ethylene evolution at -0.165 V vs. an RHE in 10 M potassium hydroxide occurs almost simultaneously with CO prodn. Operational stability was enhanced via the introduction of a polymer-based gas diffusion layer that sandwiches the reaction interface between sep. hydrophobic and conductive supports, providing const. ethylene selectivity for an initial 150 operating hours.

Oxide-derived Cu (OD-Cu) electrodes exhibit higher activity than pristine Cu during the CO2 redn. reaction (CO2RR) and higher selectivity towards ethylene. The presence of residual subsurface O in OD-Cu probably is responsible for such improvements, although its stability under the reductive CO2RR conditions remains unclear. This work sheds light on the nature and stability of subsurface O. The authors' spectroscopic results show that O is primarily concd. in an amorphous 1-2 nm thick layer within the Cu subsurface, confirming that subsurface O is stable during CO2RR for up to 1 h at -1.15 V vs. RHE. Besides, it is assocd. with a high d. of defects in the OD-Cu structure. Probably both low-coordination of the amorphous OD-Cu surface and the presence of subsurface O that withdraws charge from the Cu sp.- and d-bands might selectively enhance the binding energy of CO.

Cu electrocatalysts derived from an oxide showed extraordinary electrochem. properties for the CO2 redn. reaction (CO2RR). Using in situ ambient pressure XPS and quasi in situ EELS in a transmission electron microscope, there is a substantial amt. of residual O in nanostructured, oxide-derived Cu electrocatalysts but no residual Cu oxide. From these findings in combination with d. functional theory simulations, probably residual subsurface O changes the electronic structure of the catalyst and creates sites with higher CO binding energy. If such sites are stable under the strongly reducing conditions found in CO2RR, these findings would explain the high efficiencies of oxide-derived Cu in reducing CO2 to multicarbon compds. such as ethylene.

Oxide-derived (OD) Cu catalysts have high selectivity towards the formation of multi-C products (C2/C3) for aq. electrochem. CO2 redn. (CO2R). It has been proposed that a large fraction of the initial oxide can be surprisingly resistant to redn., and these residual oxides play a crucial catalytic role. The stability of residual oxides was studied by synthesizing 18O-enriched OD Cu catalysts and testing them for CO2R. These catalysts maintain a high selectivity towards C2/C3 products (∼60%) for ≤5 h in 0.1M KHCO3 at -1.0 V vs. RHE. However, secondary-ion mass spectrometry measurements show that only a small fraction (<1%) of the original 18O content remains, showing that residual oxides are not present in significant amts. during CO2R. We show that OD Cu can reoxidize rapidly, which could compromise the accuracy of ex situ methods for detg. the true oxygen content.

It has recently been proposed that subsurface O is crucial for the adsorption and subsequent electroredn. of CO2 on Cu. Using d. functional theory, the authors have studied the stability and diffusion of subsurface O in single crystals of Cu exposing (111) and (100) facets. O is at least 1.5 eV more stable on the surface than beneath it for both crystal orientations; interstitial sites are too small to accommodate O. The rate of at. O diffusion from one layer below a Cu(111) surface to the surface is 5 × 103 s-1. O can survive longer in deeper layers, but it does not promote CO2 adsorption there. Diffusion of subsurface O is easier to the less-dense Cu(100) surface, even from lower layers (rate ≈ 1 × 107 s-1). Once the applied voltage and dispersion forces are properly modeled, subsurface O is unnecessary for CO2 adsorption on Cu.
